title: Analysis of Func with Int by Parts and Taylor Poly

content.question: NO CALCULATOR IS ALLOWED FOR THIS QUESTION.Show all of your work, even though the question may not explicitly remind you to do so. Clearly label any functions, graphs, tables, or other objects that you use. Justifications require that you give mathematical reasons, and that you verify the needed conditions under which relevant theorems, properties, definitions, or tests are applied. Your work will be scored on the correctness and completeness of your methods as well as your answers. Answers without supporting work will usually not receive credit.Unless otherwise specified, answers (numeric or algebraic) need not be simplified. If your answer is given as a decimal approximation, it should be correct to three places after the decimal point.Unless otherwise specified, the domain of a function <math alttext="f" display="inline" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is assumed to be the set of all real numbers <math alttext="x" display="inline" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> for which <math alttext="f of x" display="inline" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> is a real number. <math alttext="The figure presents a four row table with nine columns of data. The heading for row 1 is “x.” The heading for row 2 is “g of x.” The heading for row 3 is “g prime of x.” The heading for row 4 is “g double prime of x.” The data in the table are as follows. Column 1. x is 0. g of x is 1. g prime of x is 3. g double prime of x is negative 4. Column 2. 0 is less than x, is less than 2. g of x is Positive. g prime of x is Positive. g double prime of x is Negative. Column 3. x is 2. g of x is 4. g prime of x is 0. g double prime of x is 0. Column 4. 2 is less than x, is less than 3. g of x is Positive. g prime of x is Positive. g double prime of x is Positive. Column 5. x is 3. g of x is 6. g prime of x is 4. g double prime of x is 0. Column 6. 3 is less than x, is less than 4. g of x is Positive. g prime of x is Positive. g double prime of x is Negative. Column 7. x is 4. g of x is 8. g prime of x is 0. g double prime of x is negative 2. Column 8. 4 is less than x, is less than 6. g of x is Positive. g prime of x is Negative. g double prime of x is Negative. Column 9. x is 6. g of x is 4. g prime of x is negative 4. g double prime of x is negative 2." display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mtable align="baseline" columnlines="solid" equalrows="true" frame="solid" rowalign="baseline" rowlines="solid" width="auto"><mtr><mtd><mi>x</mi></mtd><mtd><mn>0</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>0</mn><mo><</mo><mi>x</mi><mo><</mo><mn>2</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>2</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>2</mn><mo><</mo><mi>x</mi><mo><</mo><mn>3</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>3</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>3</mn><mo><</mo><mi>x</mi><mo><</mo><mn>4</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>4</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>4</mn><mo><</mo><mi>x</mi><mo><</mo><mn>6</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>6</mn></mtd></mtr><mtr><mtd><mi>g</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mtd><mtd><mn>1</mn></mtd><mtd><mtext>Positive</mtext></mtd><mtd><mn>4</mn></mtd><mtd><mtext>Positive</mtext></mtd><mtd><mn>6</mn></mtd><mtd><mtext>Positive</mtext></mtd><mtd><mn>8</mn></mtd><mtd><mtext>Positive</mtext></mtd><mtd><mn>4</mn></mtd></mtr><mtr><mtd><msup><mrow><mi>g</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>′</mo></mrow></msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mtd><mtd><mn>3</mn></mtd><mtd><mtext>Positive</mtext></mtd><mtd><mn>0</mn></mtd><mtd><mtext>Positive</mtext></mtd><mtd><mn>4</mn></mtd><mtd><mtext>Positive</mtext></mtd><mtd><mn>0</mn></mtd><mtd><mtext>Negative</mtext></mtd><mtd><mo>−</mo><mn>4</mn></mtd></mtr><mtr><mtd><msup><mrow><mi>g</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>′</mo><mo>′</mo></mrow></msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mtd><mtd><mo>−</mo><mn>4</mn></mtd><mtd><mtext>Negative</mtext></mtd><mtd><mn>0</mn></mtd><mtd><mtext>Positive</mtext></mtd><mtd><mn>0</mn></mtd><mtd><mtext>Negative</mtext></mtd><mtd><mo>−</mo><mn>2</mn></mtd><mtd><mtext>Negative</mtext></mtd><mtd><mo>−</mo><mn>2</mn></mtd></mtr></mtable></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> Let <math alttext="g" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>g</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> be a twice-differentiable function. The function <math alttext="g" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>g</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> and its derivatives have the properties indicated in the table above. (a) Find the average rate of change of <math alttext="g prime" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mrow><msup><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mi>g</mi></mrow></mstyle></mrow><mrow><mo>′</mo></mrow></msup></mrow></math> over the interval <math alttext="open bracket, 0 comma 6, close bracket" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mo>[</mo><mn>0</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>6</mn><mo>]</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>. Show the computations that lead to your answer.

Clearly label any functions, graphs, tables, or other objects that you use. Justifications require that you give mathematical reasons, and that you verify the needed conditions under which relevant theorems, properties, definitions, or tests are applied. Your work will be scored on the correctness and completeness of your methods as well as your answers. Answers without supporting work will usually not receive credit.Unless otherwise specified, answers (numeric or algebraic) need not be simplified. If your answer is given as a decimal approximation, it should be correct to three places after the decimal point.Unless otherwise specified, the domain of a function <math alttext="f" display="inline" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is assumed to be the set of all real numbers <math alttext="x" display="inline" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> for which <math alttext="f of x" display="inline" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> is a real number. <math alttext="The figure presents a four row table with nine columns of data. The heading for row 1 is “x.” The heading for row 2 is “g of x.” The heading for row 3 is “g prime of x.” The heading for row 4 is “g double prime of x.” The data in the table are as follows. Column 1. x is 0. g of x is 1. g prime of x is 3. g double prime of x is negative 4. Column 2. 0 is less than x, is less than 2. g of x is Positive. g prime of x is Positive. g double prime of x is Negative. Column 3. x is 2. g of x is 4. g prime of x is 0. g double prime of x is 0. Column 4. 2 is less than x, is less than 3. g of x is Positive. g prime of x is Positive. g double prime of x is Positive. Column 5. x is 3. g of x is 6. g prime of x is 4. g double prime of x is 0. Column 6. 3 is less than x, is less than 4. g of x is Positive. g prime of x is Positive. g double prime of x is Negative. Column 7. x is 4. g of x is 8. g prime of x is 0. g double prime of x is negative 2. Column 8. 4 is less than x, is less than 6. g of x is Positive. g prime of x is Negative. g double prime of x is Negative. Column 9. x is 6. g of x is 4. g prime of x is negative 4. g double prime of x is negative 2." display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mtable align="baseline" columnlines="solid" equalrows="true" frame="solid" rowalign="baseline" rowlines="solid" width="auto"><mtr><mtd><mi>x</mi></mtd><mtd><mn>0</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>0</mn><mo><</mo><mi>x</mi><mo><</mo><mn>2</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>2</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>2</mn><mo><</mo><mi>x</mi><mo><</mo><mn>3</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>3</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>3</mn><mo><</mo><mi>x</mi><mo><</mo><mn>4</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>4</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>4</mn><mo><</mo><mi>x</mi><mo><</mo><mn>6</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>6</mn></mtd></mtr><mtr><mtd><mi>g</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mtd><mtd><mn>1</mn></mtd><mtd><mtext>Positive</mtext></mtd><mtd><mn>4</mn></mtd><mtd><mtext>Positive</mtext></mtd><mtd><mn>6</mn></mtd><mtd><mtext>Positive</mtext></mtd><mtd><mn>8</mn></mtd><mtd><mtext>Positive</mtext></mtd><mtd><mn>4</mn></mtd></mtr><mtr><mtd><msup><mrow><mi>g</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>′</mo></mrow></msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mtd><mtd><mn>3</mn></mtd><mtd><mtext>Positive</mtext></mtd><mtd><mn>0</mn></mtd><mtd><mtext>Positive</mtext></mtd><mtd><mn>4</mn></mtd><mtd><mtext>Positive</mtext></mtd><mtd><mn>0</mn></mtd><mtd><mtext>Negative</mtext></mtd><mtd><mo>−</mo><mn>4</mn></mtd></mtr><mtr><mtd><msup><mrow><mi>g</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>′</mo><mo>′</mo></mrow></msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mtd><mtd><mo>−</mo><mn>4</mn></mtd><mtd><mtext>Negative</mtext></mtd><mtd><mn>0</mn></mtd><mtd><mtext>Positive</mtext></mtd><mtd><mn>0</mn></mtd><mtd><mtext>Negative</mtext></mtd><mtd><mo>−</mo><mn>2</mn></mtd><mtd><mtext>Negative</mtext></mtd><mtd><mo>−</mo><mn>2</mn></mtd></mtr></mtable></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> Let <math alttext="g" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>g</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> be a twice-differentiable function. The function <math alttext="g" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>g</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> and its derivatives have the properties indicated in the table above. (a) Find the average rate of change of <math alttext="g prime" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mrow><msup><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mi>g</mi></mrow></mstyle></mrow><mrow><mo>′</mo></mrow></msup></mrow></math> over the interval <math alttext="open bracket, 0 comma 6, close bracket" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mo>[</mo><mn>0</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>6</mn><mo>]</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>. Show the computations that lead to your answer.

(b) Find the <math alttext="x" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>-coordinate of each point of inflection of the graph of <math alttext="g" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>g</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> on the open interval <math alttext="0 is less than x, is less than 6" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0</mn><mo><</mo><mi>x</mi><mo><</mo><mn>6</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>. Justify your answers.

(c) Use a right Riemann sum with the three subintervals <math alttext="open bracket, 0 comma 2, close bracket" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mo>[</mo><mn>0</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>]</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>, <math alttext="open bracket, 2 comma 3, close bracket" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mo>[</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>3</mn><mo>]</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>, and <math alttext="open bracket, 3 comma 4, close bracket" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mo>[</mo><mn>3</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>4</mn><mo>]</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> to approximate <math alttext="the integral from 0 to 4, of, g of x, d x" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mrow><mrow><msubsup><mrow><mo>∫</mo></mrow><mrow><mn>0</mn></mrow><mrow><mn>4</mn></mrow></msubsup><mrow><mi>g</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>ⅆ</mo><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mrow></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math>. Show the computations that lead to your answer.

(d) Is the approximation from part (c) an overestimate or underestimate for <math alttext="the integral from 0 to 4, of, g of x, d x" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mrow><mrow><msubsup><mrow><mo>∫</mo></mrow><mrow><mn>0</mn></mrow><mrow><mn>4</mn></mrow></msubsup><mrow><mi>g</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>ⅆ</mo><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mrow></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> ? Give a reason for your answer.

(e) Find the value of <math alttext="the integral from 0 to 3, of, x times g double prime of x, d x" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mrow><mrow><msubsup><mrow><mo>∫</mo></mrow><mrow><mn>0</mn></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msubsup><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>⋅</mo><msup><mrow><mi>g</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>′</mo><mo>′</mo></mrow></msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>ⅆ</mo><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mrow></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math>. Show the computations that lead to your answer.

(f) Write the second-degree Taylor polynomial for <math alttext="g" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>g</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> about <math alttext="x equals 4" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>4</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>.

topic.text: 2.1: Defining Average and Instantaneous Rates of Change at a Point

skill.text: Skill 1.D: Identify an appropriate mathematical rule or procedure based on the relationship between concepts (e.g., rate of change and accumulation) or processes (e.g., differentiation and its inverse process, anti-differentiation) to solve problems.
